General Remarks  Commercially available reagents were obtained from Chempur, Fisher Scientific, abcr, Alfa Aesar, Sigma- Aldrich and have been used without further purification unless otherwise mentioned. 5,5',5'' -(ethane- 1,1,1 -triyl)tris(1H -pyrrole -2-carbaldehyde) 1,[S1] (2,4,6 -trimethylbenzene- 1,3,5- triyl)trimethanamine 2-Me,[S2] (2,4,6 -triethylbenzene-1,3,5- triyl)trimethanamine 2-Et[S2] and (2,4,6- tripropoxybenzene- 1,3,5 -triyl)trimethanamine 2-OPr[S3] were  synthesized according to procedures reported in literature. Melti ng points (not corrected) were measured with a B¨¹chi B -540 melting point analyser . NMR spectra were taken on Bruker Avance III 600 (600 MHz) and Bruker Avance III 700 (700 MHz) spectrometers. NMR spectra were internally referenced to residual solvent peaks  in CDCl3 (1H NMR: ¦Ä = 7.26 ppm, 13C NMR: 77.2 ppm). IR -Spectra were recorded on a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer on a ZnSe ATR crystal. MALDI -TOF experiments were carried out at a Bruker timsTOFfleX  spectrometer, both with DCTB ( trans -2-[3-(4-tert-butylphenyl) -2-methyl -2-propenylidene]malononitrile) as matrix. Crystal structure analysis was accomplished on a STOE Stadivari diffractometer with a copper source ( ¦Ë CuK¦Á = 1.54178 ?) and a PILATUS detector. Data processing and absorption correction (X -Area LANA 1.83.8.0)[S4] were accomplished by st andard methods.  Recycling gel permeation chromatography (rGPC) was carried out using a Shimadzu Prominence LC20 system with a  DGU- 20A3R degassing unit, a LC20AD pump unit, a CTO -20AC column oven, Ca BM-20A communication bus module, a SPD-M20A diode array detector,  an FRC-10A fraction collector  and an FCV -20AH2 valve unit  being equipped with a PSS SDV (20 ¡Á 50 mm) pre -column and SDV ( d ¡Á L = 20 ¡Á 300 mm) columns ( 3 ¡Á 100 ? for 3-Et cage ; 2 ¡Á 500 ?  and 2 ¡Á 1000 for cages  3-Me and 3-OPr).

Synthetic Procedures  Synthesis of cage compound 3 -Me +H2NMeNH2MeMeNH21HNHNNHOHCOHCCHOMe2-Me3-MeMeNNMeMeNHNNHNNMeHNN HNNHNNHNMeNHNNHNNHNNHNNHHN MeMeMeMeMe MeMeMeMeMeCHCl3, TFA (3 mol-%)60 ¡ãC, 2 d13%1234 567891011 In a 25 mL screw -capped vessel 5,5',5'' -(ethane- 1,1,1- triyl)tris(1H -pyrrole -2-carbaldehyde) 1 (61.9 mg, 0.2 mmol) and (2,4,6- trimethylbenzene- 1,3,5-triyl)trimethanamine 2-Me (41.4 mg, 0.2 mmol) were suspended in chloroform  (20 mL).

Trifluoroacetic acid  (0.1 M in CHCl 3, 60 ¦ÌL; 3 mol -%) was added to the mixture and heated to 60 ¡ãC for 2 days. After cooling to room temperature, the reaction mixture was filtered through a syringe filter (0.2 ¦Ìm pore) and concentrated by rotary evaporation. The resulting brown solid was immediately dissolved in THF , filtered through a syringe filter (0.2 ¦Ìm pore) twice and purified by recycling gel permeation chromatography (rGPC) (THF, 40¡ãC, 5 mL/min, see GPC Data section). The obtained GPC solution was concentrated, washed with n -pentane and dried in high vacuum to give 3-Me in 13 % yield (11.9 mg, 6.43 ¦Ìmol) as colorless solid. M.P.:  280 oC (decomp.). 1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl 3) ¦Ä = 8.18 ppm (s, 12H, H -6), 6.31 (d, J = 3.9 Hz, 12H, H -4), 5.38 (d, J = 3.6 Hz, 12H, H -3), 4.66 (s, 24H, H -7), 2.37 (s, 36H, H -10), 1.88 (s, 12H, H -11). 13C NMR (151 MHz, CDCl 3) ¦Ä = 152.4 ppm (C -6), 140.9(C -1), 136.6(C -8), 133.8(C -9), 130.0(C -5), 114.7(C -4), 109.6(C -3), 59.8(C -7), 41.7(C -2), 26.6(C -11), 15.8(C -10). IR (neat , ATR): ? = 3602 cm-1 (w), 3272 (w), 2978 (w), 2869 (w), 1628 (s), 1561 (m), 1479 (m), 1380 (w), 1354 (w), 1270 (m), 1245 (m), 1204 (m), 1038 (m), 1004 (m), 969 (w), 780 (s), 697 (m), 647 (m), 602 (m). HR-MS (MALDI -TOF): [M+H] + m/z = 1850.0210 (calcd. for C 116H121N24+: 1850.0201).

5  Synthesis of cage compound 3 -Et +H2NEtNH2EtEtNH21HNHNNHOHCOHCCHOMe2-Et3-EtEtEtNNMeMeNHNNHNNMeHNN HNNHNNHNMeNHNNHNNHNNHNNHHNEtEtEtEtEtEtEtEtCHCl3rt, 2d10%Et234567891011112 In a 25 mL screw -capped vessel 5,5',5'' -(ethane- 1,1,1- triyl)tris(1H -pyrrole -2-carbaldehyde) 1 (61.9 mg, 0.2 mmol) and (2,4,6- triethylbenzene- 1,3,5-triyl)trimethanamine 2-Et (49.8 mg, 0.2 mmol ) were suspended in chloroform (20 mL).

The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2 days and filtered through a syringe filter (0.2 ¦Ìm pore) and concentrated by rotary evaporation. The resulting brown solid was immediately dissolved in THF , filtered through a syringe filter (0.2 ¦Ìm pore) twice and purified by recycling gel permeation chromatography (rGPC) (THF, 40¡ãC, 5 mL/min, see GPC Data section). The obtained GPC solution was concentrated, washed with pentane and dried in high vacuum to give 3-Et in 10% yield (9.8 mg, 4.85 ¦Ìmol) as colorless solid. HR- MS (MALDI -TOF): [M+H] + m/z = 2018.2058 (calcd. for C128H145N24+: 2018.2079).   6  Synthesis of cage compound 3 -OPr +H2NONH2OONH21HNHNNHOHCOHCCHOMe2-OPr3-OPrOPrPrONNMeMeNHNNHNNMeHNN HNNHNNHNMeNHNNHNNHNNHNNHHNOPrPrOOPrPrO OPrOOPrPrOPrOCHCl3rt, 2d18%OPr1234 5678910131112 In a 25 mL screw -capped vessel 5,5',5'' -(ethane- 1,1,1- triyl)tris(1H -pyrrole -2-carbaldehyde) 1 (61.9 mg, 0.2 mmol)  and (2,4,6- tripropoxybenzene- 1,3,5 -triyl)trimethanamine 2-OPr (67.9 mg, 0.2 mmol)  were suspended in 16 mL chloroform.

The mixtures were stirred at room temperature for 2 days, filtered through syringe filters (0.2 ¦Ìm pore) and concentrated by rotary evaporation. The resulting brown solid was immediately dissolved in THF , filtered through a syringe filter (0.2 ¦Ìm pore) twice and purified by recycling gel permeation chromatography (rGPC) (THF, 40¡ãC, 5 mL/min, see GPC Data section). The obtained GPC solution was concentrated, added with pentane and put at room temperature overnight. The supernatant solvents were removed by a pipette technique and the residual was dried in high vacuum to give 3-OPr in 18 % yield (21.5 mg, 9.04 ¦Ìmol) as colorless solid. M.P.:  280 oC (decomp.). 1H NMR (700 MHz, CDCl 3) ¦Ä = 8.16 ppm (s, 12H, H -6), 6.29 (d, J  = 2.9 Hz, 12H, H -4), 5.39 (d, J = 2.9 Hz, 12H, H -3), 4.62 (s, 24H, H -7), 3.86 (t, J = 6.8 Hz, 24H, H -10), 1.96 (s, 12H, H -13), 1.79 ¨C 1.65 (m, 24H, H -11), 0.92 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 36H, H -12). 13C NMR (176 MHz, CDCl 3) ¦Ä = 158.5 ppm (C -9), 152.8(C -6), 141.1(C -1), 129.8(C -5), 123.3(C -8), 115.0(C -4), 109.6(C -3), 77.0(C -10), 54.6(C -7), 41.6(C -2), 25.9(C -13), 23.5(C -11), 10.7(C -12). HR-MS (MALDI -TOF): [M+H] + m/z = 2378.3341 (calcd. for C 140H169N24+: 2378.3346).

7  Synthesis of cage compound 3 -Br +H2NBrNH2BrBrNH21HNHNNHOHCOHCCHOMe2-Br3-BrBrBrNNMeMeNHNNHNNMeHNN HNNHNNHNMeNHNNHNNHNNHNNHHNBrBrBrBr BrBrBrBrBrCHCl3, TFA(3 mol-%)60¡ãC, 2dBr In a 25 mL screw -capped vessel 5,5',5'' -(ethane- 1,1,1- triyl)tris(1H -pyrrole -2-carbaldehyde) 1 (30.9 mg, 0.1 mmol) and (2,4,6- tribromobenzene- 1,3,5 -triyl)trimethanamine 2-Br (40.1 mg, 0.1 mmol)  were suspended in 20 mL chlor oform.

3 mol -% TFA (0.1 M in CHCl 3, 30 ¦ÌL) was added to the mixture and heated to 60 ¡ãC for 2 days. After cooling to room temperature, the reaction mixture was filtered through a syringe filter (0.2 ¦Ìm pore) and concentrated by rotary evaporation and washed with methanol to give 3- Br crude product (14 mg, 5.33 ¦Ìmol) as colorless solid. Note : 3-Br can¡¯t be purified further due to its poor  solubility.  1H NMR (700 MHz, CDCl 3) ¦Ä = 8.22 ppm (12H), 6.35 (12H), 5.43 (12H), 5.08 (24H), 1.92 (12H). HR-MS (MALDI -TOF): [M+H] + m/z = 2618.7490 (calcd. for C 104H85Br12N24+: 2618.7568).

53,54To ex-tend the portfolio of organic cage compounds, we envi-sioned the synthesis of tetrahedral [4 + 4] imine cages,which are based on a trispyrrol aldehyde, a unit used by Beerand co-workers for flexible [2 + 3] cages,55,56yet this timewith substituted 1,3,5-trimethylamino benzenes9,28to re-tain a higher degree of shape persistency.

Due to its low solubility, the purification of 3-Br by rec-GPC was not possible and attempts to remove impurities byrecrystallization failed, so that minor impurities remained.The successful synthesis of the cages was verified by1H NMR spectroscopy by the disappearance of the signals ofthe aldehyde units of 1(¦Ä= 9.13 ppm) as well as of the amineunits of 2-Me, 2-Et, 2-OPr and2-Br (¦Ä=1 . 3 0 ¨C1.63 ppm). In-stead, signals of the imine protons of cages 3-Me, 3-Et, 3-OPr and3-Br at¦Ä= 8.15 ¨C8.24 ppm were found (labeled asprotons 7 in Figure 1a ¨Cd). Furthermore, MALDI ?TOF massspectrometry shows signals at m/z 1850.0210 ( 3-Me ;c a l c :1850.0201), m/z 2018.2058 ( 3-Et; calc: 2018.2079), m/z2378.3341 ( 3?OPr; calc: 2378.3346) and m/z2618.7553 ( 3-Figure 1 a¨Cd)1H NMR spectra and of cage 3-Me (a) (600 MHz), 3-Et (b) (600 MHz), 3-OPr (c) (700 MHz) and 3-Br (d) (700 MHz) in CDCl 3. # = BHT, * =THF, $ = pentane, & = methanol. e ¨Ch) MALDI ?TOF mass spectra (matrix: DCTB) of 3-Me (a),3-Et (b), 3 -OPr (c) and 3-Br (d). Simulated (top) andexperimental (bottom) isotopic patterns are shown as insets.¡ø92¨‹? 2023. The Author(s). Organic Materials 2023 ,5,9 1¨C97K. Tian et al. Organic Materials Short CommunicationBr; 2618.7568) representing the corresponding [4 + 4] con-densates (Figure 1e ¨Ch).

For all isolated all -incages, suitable crystals for single-crystal X ?ray diffraction (SCXRD) analyses have been ob-tained, unambiguously proving the molecular structures ofthe [4 + 4] cages (Figure 3). The geometrical shapes can bestbe described as truncated cubes with tetrahedral symmetry.In all studied cases, the central methyl group of the trispyr-rols is pointing into the cage cavities resulting in distances toadjacent phenyl rings of dMe-Ph =1 . 2 ¨C1.3 nm and outer di-ameters of d=1 . 5 ¨C1.6 nm. As previously observed, for 3-Meall ethyl substituents are conformationally stable andpoint outwards, whereas propoxy groups in 3-OPr point ei-ther out- or inwards.
